factoid: The Karágins’ house was the most agreeable and hospitable in Moscow during winter.
The Karágins’ house hosted formal evening and dinner parties.
A large company of chiefly men gathered at the Karágins’ house every day.
The daily gatherings at the Karágins’ house involved supping at midnight and staying until three in the morning.
Julie never missed a ball, a promenade, or a play.
Julie’s dresses were always of the latest fashion.
Julie seemed disillusioned about everything and told everyone she did not believe in friendship or love or any of the joys of life.
Julie expected peace only yonder.
Julie adopted the tone of a person who had suffered a great disappointment, like a girl who had lost the man she loved or been cruelly deceived by him.
Nothing of the kind had happened to Julie, but she was regarded in that light.
Julie had come to believe that she had suffered much in life.
Julie’s melancholy did not prevent her from amusing herself.
Julie’s melancholy did not hinder the young people who came to her house from passing the time pleasantly.
Every visitor who came to the Karágins’ house paid tribute to Julie’s melancholy mood.
Every visitor then amused themselves with society gossip, dancing, intellectual games, and bouts rimés.
Bouts rimés were in vogue at the Karágins’ house.
Only a few young men, among them Borís, entered more deeply into Julie’s melancholy.
Julie had prolonged private conversations with Borís about the vanity of all worldly things.
Julie showed Borís her albums filled with mournful sketches, maxims, and verses.
To Borís, Julie was particularly gracious.
Julie regretted Borís’s early disillusionment with life.
Julie offered Borís such consolation of friendship as she could render.
Julie showed Borís her album.
Borís sketched two trees in the album and wrote: “Rustic trees, your dark branches shed gloom and melancholy upon me.”
On another page Borís drew a tomb and wrote a French passage about death.
Julie said the French passage was charming.
Julie said: “There is something so enchanting in the smile of melancholy,” and repeated a passage she had copied from a book.
Julie said the passage was a ray of light in the darkness, a shade between sadness and despair, showing the possibility of consolation.
In reply, Borís wrote lines in French about poisonous nourishment of a too sensitive soul.

Borís wrote: “Poisonous nourishment of a too sensitive soul, Thou, without whom happiness would for me be impossible, Tender melancholy, ah, come to console me, Come to calm the torments of my gloomy retreat, And mingle a secret sweetness with these tears that I feel to be flowing.”
For Borís, Julie played most doleful nocturnes on her harp.
Borís read Poor Liza aloud to Julie.
Borís interrupted the reading more than once because of the emotions that choked him.
At large gatherings, Julie and Borís looked on one another as the only souls who understood one another in a world of indifferent people.
Anna Mikháylovna often visited the Karágins.
Anna Mikháylovna played cards with Julie.
Anna Mikháylovna made careful inquiries as to Julie’s dowry.
Julie was to have two estates in Pénza and the Nizhegórod forests as her dowry.
Anna Mikháylovna regarded the refined sadness that united her son to the wealthy Julie with emotion and resignation to the Divine will.
Anna Mikháylovna said to Julie: “You are always charming and melancholy, my dear Julie.”
Anna Mikháylovna said to Julie: “Borís says his soul finds repose at your house. He has suffered so many disappointments and is so sensitive.”
Anna Mikháylovna said to her son: “Ah, my dear, I can’t tell you how fond I have grown of Julie latterly.”
Anna Mikháylovna said: “But who could help loving her? She is an angelic being!”
Anna Mikháylovna said: “Ah, Borís, Borís!” and paused.
Anna Mikháylovna said: “And how I pity Julie’s mother.”
Anna Mikháylovna said: “Today Julie showed me her accounts and letters from Pénza (they have enormous estates there), and Julie has no one to help Julie, and they cheat Julie.”
